matched.actualTitle: Authentication Bypass via X-Forwarded-For Header Spoofing / Authentication Bypass via X-Forwarded-For Header Manipulation
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the identical vulnerability where the application trusts the X-Forwarded-For HTTP header to determine authorization. The actual findings provide multiple POC validations confirming that attackers can spoof the X-Forwarded-For header with '127.0.0.1' or 'localhost' values to bypass authentication entirely and gain admin access. This directly matches the expected finding's description of the vulnerability affecting the index.php file at the specified line numbers.

extra.title: Application Not Creating Sessions - No Set-Cookie Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application has no session management mechanism implemented at all. No Set-Cookie headers are generated in any responses. This is a critical finding that enables attackers to bypass all session-based security controls and indicates incomplete authentication implementation.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Login Form
extra.assessment: New discovery - The login form lacks CSRF tokens entirely. Combined with missing session management and other vulnerabilities, this creates a complete CSRF attack vector. This is a significant security gap that should be addressed.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application is missing critical security headers including X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, Content-Security-Policy, X-XSS-Protection, and Strict-Transport-Security. These headers provide defense-in-depth against multiple attack vectors.

extra.title: Missing Authentication Validation - All Credentials Accepted
extra.assessment: New discovery - The authentication system performs no credential validation whatsoever. All login attempts receive identical responses regardless of credentials submitted. This represents a complete failure of the authentication mechanism beyond just the X-Forwarded-For header issue.

extra.title: Arbitrary Cookie Values Accepted Without Validation - Session Fixation Vulnerability
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application accepts arbitrary PHPSESSID cookie values including path traversal sequences, null bytes, and special characters without any validation. This enables session fixation attacks and demonstrates complete lack of session validation.

extra.title: Server and X-Powered-By Header Version Information Disclosure
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application exposes Apache 2.4.25 and PHP 5.6.40 version information in HTTP response headers. This reconnaissance information helps attackers identify known vulnerabilities in specific versions.

extra.title: No Rate Limiting on Login Attempts - Brute Force Vulnerability
extra.assessment: New discovery - The authentication endpoint has no rate limiting, account lockout, or brute force protection mechanisms. Attackers can perform unlimited login attempts without any throttling or penalties.

extra.title: Apache Server Version Disclosure in 404 Error Page
extra.assessment: New discovery - Custom 404 error pages have not been implemented, and Apache's default error page exposes the server version 'Apache/2.4.25 (Debian)' in the HTML body. This information is accessible to anyone accessing non-existent resources.

extra.title: 403 Forbidden Error Page Reveals Server Version and Path Information
extra.assessment: New discovery - Apache's default 403 error pages expose both the server version and requested file paths, providing reconnaissance information to attackers attempting to access restricted resources.

extra.title: No SameSite Cookie Attribute - Vulnerable to CSRF Attacks
extra.assessment: New discovery - When session cookies are eventually implemented, they will lack SameSite attributes, leaving the application vulnerable to CSRF attacks. This is a prospective vulnerability that should be addressed in the implementation design.

extra.title: 405 Method Not Allowed Error Page Discloses Server Version
extra.assessment: New discovery - Apache's default 405 error pages for unsupported HTTP methods expose the server version 'Apache/2.4.25 (Debian)' in the error page footer. This provides another information disclosure vector.

extra.title: 400 Bad Request Error Page Discloses Apache Server Version
extra.assessment: New discovery - Apache's default 400 error pages for malformed HTTP requests expose the server version in both headers and HTML body. Any client sending malformed requests receives detailed version information.

extra.title: Outdated Software Versions - Apache 2.4.25 and PHP 5.6.40
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application is running on outdated software versions (Apache 2.4.25 from 2016, PHP 5.6.40 which is end-of-life). These versions have multiple known CVEs and should be updated to receive security patches.
